com.martinandersson.javaee.ejb.inheritance

Class InheritanceAndSpecializesTest

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.martinandersson.javaee.ejb.inheritance.InheritanceAndSpecializesTest

  • public class InheritanceAndSpecializesTest
extends Object
    This test will examine what happens when you extend an EJB, and what happens when you go one step further and @Specializes one.

    For all the details, see the individual test cases. Here's a summary:

    If EJB B extends EJB A, both are available and ready to be used by means of the ordinary @EJB injection mechanism. However, using @Inject to lookup A will cause ambiguity (crash). This result is the same for GlassFish 4.1 and WildFly 9.0.0.CR1.

    The result of the following case is independent of whether @EJB or @Inject is used.

    If EJB C extends EJB A, but C also declare the CDI annotation @Specializes, then C can be looked up. But trying to lookup A will make GlassFish crash (something inside GlassFish has understood that A is supposed to be disabled) while WildFly route the call to an instance of A (ignoring that it was "specialized" by B).

    The lessons to be learned is 1) when you write EJB injection points, stick to @EJB. If you use @Inject, then new subclass additions in the future will brake your code. 2) Do not declare @Specializes on an EJB. It is not possible to properly specialize an EJB bean in GlassFish nor in WildFly.

    Author:
    Martin Andersson (webmaster at martinandersson.com)

    • Method Detail

      • test_inheritance_lookupUsingEJB

        @OperateOnDeployment(value="-without-c")
public void test_inheritance_lookupUsingEJB()
        This test demonstrates that if EJB B extends EJB A, both are available and ready to be used by means of the ordinary @EJB injection mechanism.

        "@EJB A a;" does not cause ambiguity. Nor does the subclass B cause superclass A to be disabled.

      • test_inheritance_lookupUsingInject

        @OperateOnDeployment(value="-without-c")
public void test_inheritance_lookupUsingInject()
        ..but if we use CDI (@Inject) to lookup B, then everything changes.

        Both GlassFish 4.1 and WildFly 9.0.0.CR1 will throw javax.enterprise.inject.AmbiguousResolutionException when trying to inject A because there is two different bean classes that qualify for bean type A.

        Using @Inject instead of @EJB can cause troubles in other scenarios too and it is only necessarily to use CDI when you want to scope the life cycle of a @Stateful EJB. In all other cases, there is no point in using @Inject when looking for EJB:s.

        Note that CDI.current().select.. is equivalent to @Inject.

      • test_specializes_lookupUsingEJB

        @OperateOnDeployment(value="-with-c")
public void test_specializes_lookupUsingEJB()
                                                                            throws NamingException
        What if the subclass B not only extends A, but also declare the CDI annotation @Specializes?

        When specializing a CDI bean, the superclass will become disabled (in theory at least1). Does the same hold true when we specialize an EJB? Does it matter to the outcome which lookup method we use (@EJB versus @Inject)?

        This test uses @EJB, but the result doesn't change if you use @Inject as is proved by the next test case.

        The result is different between GlassFish 4.1 and WildFly 9.0.0.CR1.

        In GlassFish, class A is injected with a proxy. But if we try to dereference that proxy, then Weld crash with a NPE deep down the stack2.

        WildFly inject a proxy to A and let us dereference the reference to an instance of A.

        It can therefore be said that GlassFish does to a certain extent what is expected by @Specializes (turning A into a disabled bean3), alas a bit too late. WildFly seem to reason that @Specializes is a CDI construct and won't bother about disabling A. It is business as usual.

        None of the server did what was fully expected of the @Specializes annotation: Disable A and route the call to an instance of B.

        As far as I can tell, it is not defined by the CDI- and EJB specification what should happen when specializing EJB:s. Thus both behaviors are accepted by this test.

        TODO: File a CDI bug (actually, file an EJB bug and ask them to prune the spec).

        Note 1

        See SpecializesTest.

        Note 2

        Here's what the client see: 
         javax.ejb.EJBException: javax.ejb.EJBException: javax.ejb.CreateException: Could not create stateless EJB
     Caused by: javax.ejb.EJBException: javax.ejb.CreateException: Could not create stateless EJB
     Caused by: javax.ejb.CreateException: Could not create stateless EJB
     Caused by: java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
     Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
         ...
         at com.sun.ejb.containers.BaseContainer.createEjbInstanceAndContext(BaseContainer.java:1696)

        Note 3

        In this particular use case. We have not tested what happens to CDI observers and producer methods that could be declared in class A. Even more so, I bet that life cycle callback methods et cetera is called on A (TODO: Examine).
        Throws:
        NamingException

        Same results as previous test case.
